titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Fort Pitt Bridge Works, Pittsburgh, Pa. Records, 1886-1949 AIS.1963.27
titlestmt.author: Archives Service Center Staff. Revisions occurred to the finding aid as a part of the encoding process on October 18, 1999.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:16:58 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Fort Pitt Bridge Works, Pittsburgh, Pa., Records
did.abstract: The Fort Pitt Bridge Works was engaged in the construction of steel bridges and mill buildings, the production of structural steel work and reinforcing steel for road work and buildings, the pressing and welding heavy plate sections, and the engineering and manufacturing of combustion systems for industrial furnaces. This collection contains records regarding the organization and operation of the Fort Pitt Bridge Works including minutes, tax records, articles of incorporation, etc.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Fort Pitt Bridge Works of Pittsburgh, Pa., was formed in May of 1896 by the merger of the Pittsburgh Architectural Iron Works with Straub and Bickle. The Pittsburgh Architectural Iron Works was operated by George Delenbacker and William and George Ebenhardt, who owned a small steel making plant in Cannonsburg, PA. Straub and Bickle was an engineering and contracting firm headed by Theodore Straub and H.R. Bickle. In 1930 the Fort Pitt Bridge Works purchased the Massillon Bridge and Structural Steel Works of Massillon, Ohio. On January 1, 1946 the Fort Pitt Bridge Works became a wholly-owned subsidiary by the Electric Welding Company.

The Fort Pitt Bridge Works provided steel for projects in Pittsburgh and across the nation. Nationally, the Fort Pitt Bridge Works contributed to projects such as the construction of the Lackawana Steel Company building in Buffalo, NY. The corporation also provided the steel used in the construction of the Jefferson Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Fort Pitt Bridge Works was also active in the war effort in both World War I and World War II. The Fort Pitt Bridge Works made a great many contributions locally including the construction of the Pennsylvania Turnpike and much of Pittsburgh's infrastructure. Many of Pittsburgh's bridges (the Sewickly Bridge, the McKees Rocks Bridge, Point Bridge, the 16th Street Bridge, the 31st Street Bridge, Smithfield Street Bridge, Bloomfield Bridge, California Avenue Bridge, Wilmot Street Bridge, and many of the bridges on the Penn-Lincoln Parkway) and Pittsburgh's steel frame buildings (the Sheraton Hotel, the Pittsburgh Press Building, Psychiatric Hospital, the Federal Building and the Syria Mosque) are the results of steel from the Fort Pitt Bridge Works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the records of the Fort Pitt Bridge Works, known before 1930 as the Fort Pitt Bridge Works of Pittsburgh, PA, which was incorporated in 1896. In addition it contains the records of its predecessor, the Pittsburgh Architectural Iron Works, as well as the records from the Massillon Bridge and Structural Steel Works of Massillon, OH, which was purchased by Fort Pitt in 1930. There are also records from the Massillon Steel Erecting Company and the Flint Structural Steel Company, Massillon, OH, both of which were absorbed into the Fort Pitt Bridge Works. These records include documents pertaining to the company's incorporation, information regarding stockholders and the company stock, correspondence, news clippings and other printed matter covering the period from 1896 through 1946 when Fort Pitt was purchased by the Electric Welding Company.
Records on microfilm are identified by the following record group abbreviations:

Fort Pitt Bridge Works Records are identified as "FPBW" Massillon Bridge and Structural Steel Works of Massillon, Ohio are identified as "MBSSW" Pittsburgh Architectural Iron Works Records are identified as "PAIW"

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Donald Straub on December 5, 1963.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Permission for publication is given on behalf of the University of Pittsburgh as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission of the copyright holder, which must also be obtained.
